awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Healthcare Austerity and the Mobilization of Social Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Reductions in state-sponsored forms of healthcare are an increasingly common response to economic crisis. When public programs and private financial resources both recede, what kinds of social resources do chronically ill people, who need stable access to pharmaceuticals, mobilize in order to survive? Social scientific accounts of unmet healthcare needs associated with economic crises have largely focused on the developing world. Less is known about the relationship between austerity and healthcare resources in contexts such as the U.S. or Europe. This research addresses pharmaceutical access under austerity in a context with a previously robust universal healthcare system. Deepening financial and healthcare inequalities associated with economic crisis have given way to newly disenfranchised people that must seek pharmaceuticals in a therapeutic economy characterized by frequent crisis-driven reformulations. This research, which is centered on training a graduate student in rigorous methods of scientific data collection and analysis, seeks to understand the kinds of social resources people mobilize in order to address unmet pharmaceutical needs, when public healthcare is no longer dependable and financial resources and pharmaceuticals are unevenly distributed. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student, the project would improve scientific understanding through broadly disseminating its findings to governmental and non-governmental organizations charged with improving public health access, as they mediate the differential impacts of austerity on healthcare outcomes.
  
Taylor Bell, under the supervision of Dr. Cristiana Giordano of the University of California at Davis, will explore what forms of social networks replace public infrastructures under conditions of austerity in healthcare access. This research takes place in Athens, Greece, which has instituted the most stringent austerity measures targeting public healthcare across Europe. Athens has the highest concentration of state-sponsored healthcare resources in Greece, and so, will best highlight how people adjust pharmaceutical-seeking practices when public resources disappear. In order to learn how pharmaceuticals are exchanged and the relationships that facilitate these exchanges, the co-PI will conduct participant observation in emergent grassroots solidarity clinics and pharmacies, which many people turned to after austerity measures eroded the universal healthcare system, cutting its budget by more than 50%. The co-PI will also track, map, and analyze pharmaceutical networks and therapeutic economies through a range of observational and archival methods on extended social networks, as well as interviews (through both the McGill Illness Narrative Interview, and well as targeted semi-structured follow-ups) with a representative sample of pharmaceutical seekers. The findings will contribute to debates in medical, political, and economic anthropology about inequality, specifically in the differential distribution of healthcare burdens under conditions of economic austerity. This research offers insight to policymakers concerned with the kinds of social resources that disenfranchised, chronically ill people build in order to establish access to needed pharmaceuticals, as state-funded healthcare retracts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Graduate student Taylor Bell (co-PI), supervised by Dr. Cristiana Giordano (PI), conducted ethnographic research in Athens, Greece between 2019 and 2021. This research found that ongoing relationships between community pharmacists and their patients have served as socio-medical infrastructure that enables patients and their pharmacists to challenge emergent austerity-driven barriers to care and pharmaceuticals that are now compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic. Austerity-driven legislation began in 2010 at the insistence of Greece’s transnational creditors and took particular aim at state-subsidized healthcare and pharmaceutical spending. Quick, drastic cuts in spending, amongst other austerity-driven policy changes, triggered shortages of pharmaceuticals and increasing inaccessibility of clinical care. These austerity measures also recast Greece’s pharmaceutical economy and the figure of the pharmacist. Contrasting representations emerged: the upselling community pharmacist, responsible for Greece’s high pharmaceutical spending and financial crisis, and the grassroots solidarity pharmacist who distributes donated pharmaceuticals to those in need.

 

 

A primary finding of this research is that these domains are not as separate as they initially seem. The ability of community pharmacists to provide for the needs of both their patients and their pharmacies has depended upon their enactment of a diverse economy (Gibson Graham 2014) that exceeds retail and includes practices of knowledge and pharmaceutical circulation reminiscent of solidarity pharmacy. Sometimes long-term patients lack the ability to pay for either their medication or the clinical encounter necessary to procure a prescription for it. In these cases, the community pharmacist often still gives them the medication with an understanding that the patient will return to the pharmacy with the appropriate prescription or payment when they are able.

 

A secondary finding of this research is that not only patients, but pharmacists, too, experience ongoing austerity-driven barriers to pharmaceutical access as they stock their pharmacies. Amongst other factors, austerity-driven state-mandated reductions in pharmaceutical pricing triggered rationing of pharmaceutical sales to the Greek market. To address this rationing, community pharmacists are often in continual negotiations with manufacturers, wholesalers, and other pharmacists in order to meet the needs of their patients. Many pharmacists depend on pharmacist social networks in their neighborhoods and on social media through which they trade rationed pharmaceutical products to better supply their long-term patients. Community pharmacists have become informal supply chain wranglers undertaking new and extensive practices of pharmaceutical acquisition. They forge new social networks and deepen existing ones as they facilitate pharmaceutical circulation.

 

The third finding of this research is that the role of the community pharmacist has also come to be defined by para-clinical practices. Pharmacists do not merely distribute medications deemed appropriate by doctors or requested by patients. Before distributing medications, they tend to conduct consultations, and sometimes even certain procedures or forms of measurement and testing. These practices are not an altogether new foray, as the familiar neighborhood community pharmacist has long been considered a trustworthy source of medical expertise alternative to the more anonymous and stereotypically bribery-prone figure of the doctor. However, as austerity, and later, COVID-19, made clinical care less accessible, more patients consult their pharmacist as the initial source of expertise about medical ailments and treatments.

 

The fourth finding of this study is that community pharmacists have successfully leveraged the COVID-19 pandemic as an opportunity to gain recognition and financial compensation for their changing role in Greece’s healthcare system. The para-clinical and supply-chain management skills of pharmacists became even more crucial as COVID-19 further deteriorated hospitals and disrupted medical and pharmaceutical supply chains. Community pharmacists earned contracts with the state to to sell and conduct in-pharmacy rapid COVID-19 test and register patients for state hospital-administered vaccinations. The accessibility and dense distribution of community pharmacies, the trust patients associate with them, and their already para-clinical character made them ideal sites for such crucial tasks. Conducting COVID testing and reporting diagnoses to the state has enabled private community pharmacists to highlight the skills they have cultivated through the uncompensated work of consultation, measurement, and diagnosis that they provide to patients for free. While they have long advocated for compensation for para-clinical services, a new emphasis on the official role of community pharmacists in COVID-19 testing and vaccination lends heft to ongoing efforts for formalization and compensation.

 

Austerity-driven attempts to further regulate Greece’s pharmaceutical economy created new networks of pharmaceutical circulation between pharmacists that are invisible to regulation and deepened existing ones between pharmacists and their patients. At the same time, as austerity and COVID damaged the functioning of Greece’s national healthcare system, trusted community pharmacists came to assume increasing para-clinical labor for their long-term patients. They have sought to make this labor visible, amenable to regulation, and deserving of compensation. This research illuminates the crucial role played by the long-term relationships that community pharmacists have with each other and those they have with their patients in mitigating the increasing inaccessibility of pharmaceuticals and healthcare.
